options: Do nothing as Betty has Betty has capacity to decide to live alone
Explain to Betty your concerns about her wellfare and ability to cope without any help
Ask permission for occupational therapy to visit and assess Betty and her home
Voice your concern over Betty with one of the senior GPs at your practice
Use the Mental Health Act to admit her to hospital so that a thorough assessment can be made of her dementia and ongoing needs
questions:
You are working as a GP registrar. You are conducting home visits when you notice that you have attended the next patient's home four times in the last two weeks, with you gaining the opinion during these visits that Betty, 79, is struggling to cope at home on her own. Betty has a background of mild dementia and is found to have requested a home visit today as she dropped a pan of hot water and now has a small burn on her leg that doesn't require treatment. Otherwise, Betty appears well and scores 8/10 on an Abbreviated Mental Test Score, a score consistent with previous visits. Betty assures you that she is able to cope living alone and 'wouldn't countenance going into a home or a hospital'.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The best first step is to simply explain your concern (B). Many patients, particularly elderly ones, pay a lot of attention to the views of their doctor, often more so than other concerned people such as her immediate family. This concern may act as a gateway to further interventions.

Occupational therapists (C) are well-placed to assess her ability to cope at home. This should only be done though with Bettys' permission.

Speaking to a senior colleague (D) is always helpful but does not directly benefit Betty, unlike B & C.

Doing nothing (A), as with many situations, is a poor response.

Admitting the patient against her will to hospital (E) is a very poor response.

options: Attempt to gain understanding for the patients reasoning
Involve a senior with this patient
Go ahead and treat the patient
Do not attempt to gain understanding for the patients reasoning
Find the patient's identity through other means

questions:
You are the F2 in the emergency department. A patient attends but for some reason does not want to be identified and searched in the NHS database.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
Situations like this happen reasonably frequently in clinical practice. Patients will have various reasons for not giving their details.

The most important point here is that you, as an F2 or other doctor, have a duty of care to all patients (identified or not). It is best to treat first and worry about identity later.

It is appropriate to politely and non-forceful enquiry about a patient's reasoning and to involve a senior colleague if you are suspicious.

Inappropriate actions include going behind the patient's back or reporting the patient to the authorities without valid reasoning.

options: Tell the patient that the team is currently investigating and that you will let him know the outcome when it is known
Tell the patient that the investigations to date have not shown any cause for concern
Take the patient to a side room and inform him that it is likely that he has cancer and discuss treatment options with him
Tell the patient that the team is currently investigating and that a senior member of your team will let him know the outcome when it is known
Tell the patient that he has got cancer and it is highly likely that it is terminal
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a gastroenterology ward. A patient calls you over to ask you a question. You are aware that recent investigations are highly suggestive of advanced metastatic malignancy, but results from investigations to provide a definitive diagnosis have not yet come back. The patient asks you if he is going to die from cancer.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The main themes in this scenario are honesty and recognising and working within the levels of your competence. This scenario is difficult to deal with and is something that may well occur whilst working on the wards.

The duties of a doctor, as outlined by the GMC, are as follows:

Knowledge, skills and performance
  • Make the care of your patient your first concern.
  • Provide a good standard of practice and care.
  • Keep your professional knowledge and skills up to date.
  • Recognise and work within the limits of your competence.

Safety and quality
  • Take prompt action if you think that patient safety, dignity or comfort is being compromised.
  • Protect and promote the health of patients and the public.

Communication, partnership and teamwork
  • Treat patients as individuals and respect their dignity.
  • Treat patients politely and considerately.
  • Respect patients' right to confidentiality.
  • Work in partnership with patients.
  • Listen to, and respond to, their concerns and preferences.
  • Give patients the information they want or need in a way they can understand.
  • Respect patients' right to reach decisions with you about their treatment and care.
  • Support patients in caring for themselves to improve and maintain their health.
  • Work with colleagues in the ways that best serve patients' interests.

Maintaining trust
  • Be honest and open and act with integrity.
  • Never discriminate unfairly against patients or colleagues.
  • Never abuse your patients' trust in you or the public's trust in the profession.

Keeping these qualities in mind, the most appropriate answer in this scenario is telling the patient that the team is investigating and that a senior colleague will come and speak with them when we know more (option 4). This is both being open and honest with the patient, as the team do not as yet have a definitive diagnosis, and also recognising the limitations of your abilities in saying that a senior member of the team will come and speak with them. As an ST1 doctor you may not have the necessary knowledge to speak about this patient's potential diagnosis and treatment plans.

The next most appropriate option is option 1, telling the patient that the team is currently investigating and that you will speak with them when you know more. This isn't as preferable as option 4, as you haven't recognised the potential limitations of your knowledge and may find yourself in a difficult situation with a patient asking questions for which you do not know the answers. However, this is more appropriate than option 3, speaking with the patient straight away in a side room, as the diagnosis isn't conclusive yet so telling the patient that he has cancer may actually be incorrect, and by saying that the team is currently investigating you have given yourself time to prepare for the conversation that you will have with the patient, meaning you will be more prepared.

Options 5 (telling the patient that he has cancer and that it is highly likely that it is terminal ) and option 2 (telling the patient that the investigations to date have not shown any cause for concern ) are the two worst options. Telling the patient that he has cancer (option 5) may be incorrect, as a definitive diagnosis has not been given as yet. Furthermore, even if the diagnosis is definitive telling the patient that it is highly likely to be terminal is not correct, as this is purely speculation. However, this is still preferable to option 2, in which false hope is given to a patient who likely has a terminal condition. This is misleading and goes against several of the duties of a doctor outlined by the GMC.

options: Advise that this would be better dealt with next week by the patient's usual GP
Agree to keep this information confidential
Contact the police
Contact social services
Contact the partner to inform them of the allegations
Explain that legally you must disclose this information
Give the patient another chance to contact the police before doing so yourself
Give the patient information on domestic violence support groups
Make a joint appointment with the patient and their partner to discuss the abuse
Offer a follow-up appointment
questions:
You are working in general practice when a man attends with low mood. You have not met this patient before but his usual doctor is currently on holiday. During the consultation, the man discloses that his partner is frequently both verbally and physically abusive. They have no children together and there are no other adults at risk.

The man cannot be persuaded to contact the police as he is worried about what will happen when his partner finds out he has disclosed the abuse.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This scenario involves the disclosure of abuse from a patient who does not wish to take the disclosure further. Per Good Medical Practice (2013), all patients have the right to a confidential medical service. The GMC guidance state that 'doctors should usually abide by the wishes of an adult patient who refuses consent to information being shared, even if that leaves them, but nobody else, at risk of harm.' From this scenario, there is no evidence that any children or vulnerable adults are at risk of harm from the partner. Therefore, it is appropriate to agree to keep the information confidential.

Even if a patient does not want to seek help immediately, the GMC state that they must be given information and support during the consultation. It is appropriate to give the patient information on domestic violence support groups.

Offer a follow-up appointment gives the patient time to explore the resources they have been given and consider seeking further help. It leaves the doors open for further communication and allows the ongoing provision of support.

Advise that this would be better dealt with next week by the patient's usual GP appears dismissive. The patient has chosen to disclose the abuse to you and it is your duty to handle this disclosure appropriately.

Contact the police involves breaking confidentiality. The patient is clear that they do not wish for the police to be involved. As there are no vulnerable people at risk of harm from the partner, it is not appropriate to break confidentiality.

For the same reason, contact social services is also inappropriate. Social services would also unlikely be the correct agency to refer the patient to, even if the patient did consent, as this scenario does not involve children or vulnerable adults.

Contact the partner to inform them of the allegations is inappropriate. Not only does it involve breaking confidentiality inappropriately, but it may also put the patient at risk as they now know that their partner has disclosed the abuse.

Explain that legally you must disclose this information is incorrect. As there are no children or vulnerable adults at risk, this is not a scenario in which disclosure of confidential information is required for public safety.

Give the patient another chance to contact the police before doing so yourself is also incorrect. As above, this is not a scenario in which the police need to be informed. So long as no one else is at risk, it is up to the patient whether they wish to disclose the abuse to the police.

Make a joint appointment with the patient and their partner to discuss the abuse is incorrect. It is clear from the brief that the patient feels they would be at risk if the partner knew about their disclosure.

title: GMC: Confidentiality - Disclosures for the protection of patients and others
body:
This guidance covers disclosing information in adults; there is separate GMC guidance for children.

The GMC highlight the importance of a confidential medical service. However, sometimes patients are unable to protect themselves, and we may need to disclose personal information to protect their health and welfare.

I'm worried that my patient is at risk of harm abuse or neglect- Should I disclose?

1) Empower patients- make decisions about how to best move forward in partnership

2) If disclosure is required by law- You must disclose, but only the specific requested information, in the manner required by law. Inform your patient of disclosure (unless It would undermine the purpose)

3) Some disclosures are permitted but not required by law- these should have a legal basis

4) How you act will partly depend on whether this patient has capacity or lacks capacity:

Disclosure required by lawDisclosure not required by law
Has capacityYou must discloseRequires patient consent (if practicable)- ultimately the patient's decision unless non-disclosure puts others at risk of serious harm/death. If they refuse, find out why, inform them of the risks and refer to support groups
Lacks capacityYou must discloseYou must disclose to appropriate authority/person (unless not of overall benefit to the patient). Discuss with an experienced colleague and document if you think it's not in the patient's best interest

Can I share information to protect others/the public?

Confidentiality is in the public interest as it benefits society and individuals to seek medical care. However, this must be balanced with protecting and promoting the health of patients and the public.

Required by lawRequests for informationDisclosure not required by law
You must disclose e.g. infectious disease notification, provision of social and health care, preventing terrorism and investigation of road traffic accidents.Take these seriously if patients pose a risk of serious harm (e.g. violent or sex offenders), and for formal inquiries, inquests and reviewsEither patient must consent (unless not practicable) or must have a legal basis
If you have already decided to disclose the information, don't request consent, instead inform them of this intention, unless not safe or practicable.


Deciding if you will disclose regardless of if the patient consents:

1. Would non-disclosure put others at risk of death or serious harm? - this may justify disclosure e.g.
  • When a victim of violence doesn't want to inform the police, but the perpetrator still poses a significant risk to others, such as children in domestic violence.
  • If someone keeps driving despite being told they are not fit to drive
  • A patient has a serious communicable disease but refuses to disclose
  • A patient is working despite being unfit for work and this poses a serious risk to others

2. You should only disclose if you decide that the risk of not disclosing is so serious that it outweighs the patient and public interest in maintaining confidentiality.

Pro-confidentiality factorsPro-disclosure factors
Harm/distress from disclosing may cause withdrawal from care and poor healthHarm to others if not disclosed
Disclosing will reduce overall trust in perception of doctorsBenefit to others if information disclosed

Think about the nature of the information and what the patient thinks. Can you minimise the breach of the patient's privacy and still avoid harm?

Genetic medicine introduces another hurdle in relation to confidentiality, because if your patient Is found to have a genetic condition, this might also suggest a probability of this condition in a relative. Many patients share these results with relatives especially if they know it can help to prevent health problems in their relatives. However, if a patient refuses, it would be just to disclose if non-disclosure would risk death or serious harm in others. Try to not disclose patient identity when advising the others of the risks identified to them.

Always document in patient records when disclosing information. Document steps you've taken to seek consent from or inform the patient about the disclosure, or reasons for not doing so.

Whether you can disclose without consent can be complex. Before doing so, seek advice from a Caldicott or data guardian who isn't connected to the reason for the disclosure. Keep the patient details anonymous if possible.

options: Remove her from the practice list for sexual harassment
Arrange for her to be seen by a female doctor
Insist on having a chaperone present
Phone her mother to discuss the situation
Contact the local Child Protection Officer for advice
questions:
You are a male GP registrar. During a routine surgery you see 15-year-old girl complaining of a painful knee. During the consultation she makes a comment about how you are 'better looking than my normal doctor' and asks not to have a chaperone whilst you examine her legs.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
It is not uncommon for teenagers to develop crushes on authority figures, classically teachers. This situation needs to be handled delicately. Once it is clear that a patient (young or not) has developed an abnormal interest in a doctor it is inappropriate for the doctor-patient relationship to continue. It is therefore appropriate to ensure you do not see the patient again.

The next best option is to ensure you always have a chaperone present in the room. This may help to both prevent inappropriate behaviour and protect you from any claims of improper conduct.

Contacting the Child Protection Officer for advice may be appropriate if a younger child was displaying sexual behaviour but would probably not be needed in this scenario.

Speaking to the child's mother without permission is breaking confidentiality and should be avoided if at all possible.

It is stretching it a bit to describe this child's behaviour as sexual harassment.

options: Remind him of how stretched the NHS is
Advise him to contact PALS (Patient Advisory Liaison Service)
Go back and listen to his concerns after the ward round to see if you can resolve any issues
Ask him to make a formal complaint in writing
Give the patient a choice of being more respectful or transferring to a different ward
questions:
You are a F2 doctor in medicine. During a ward round a patient who has been admitted following a stroke says he is not happy with a number of aspects of his treatment including the hospital food and lack of physiotherapy.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
When patients or their relatives feel that they have received inadequate care the first step is to try and achieve local resolution. Speaking to the health care professionals involved can often resolve any misunderstandings. If this does not resolve the issue then PALS should be contacted to try and help. If this still fails then a written complaint should be made to allow a formal response from the hospital.

All complaints should be dealt with seriously and on an individual basis. Whilst limited NHS resources will undoubtedly contribute to failings in care they should not be sighted in individual cases. Threatening the patient with removal to a different ward is the worst response.

options: Immediately call the on call consultant to tell them about the situation and how inappropriate it is
Take the bleep from the registrar doctor as you both deserve to have a break and something to eat
Immediately call the medical registrar on call to inform them of the situation and your concerns regarding patient safety
Politely tell the registrar doctor that it would not be appropriate for you to hold their bleep due to not being at their level of training
Tell the registrar that you do not want to hold their bleep
questions:
You are the F2 doctor on a general medical ward. It is 3 am on a busy night shift and both you and your registrar have been unable to stop for a break. The registrar doctor asks if you could hold their bleep whilst they go and have something to eat. They instruct you to take messages from the calls and they will deal with the jobs created when they come back from their break.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
It is common for doctors to be very busy overnight. In this situation it is important to ensure that you have an undisturbed natural break, however, patient safety should not be impacted as a consequence. The GMC state that you must always work within your competencies and abilities as a doctor, which would clearly be breached by holding the registrar's bleep.

Option D is the right answer as you are politely declining the bleep. It is always important to be polite to colleagues in all situations. This option also explains to the registrar doctor that their request is inappropriate which should hopefully facilitate a reflection.

Option E is the correct outcome however it is less appropriate as it does not involve an explanation to the registrar with regards to the reasoning.

Option C is the next appropriate option as you have escalated the problem within your team. However, it does not involve a discussion with the registrar doctor directly and is, therefore, less favourable.

Option A has several issues. Firstly, it does not involve speaking directly to the registrar doctor. Secondly, it would be inappropriate to contact the consultant on call without discussing it with the medical registrar in the first instance.

Option B is the least appropriate response. This would not be working within your capabilities, thereby resulting in a significant risk to patient safety.

title: General Medical Council: duties of a doctor
body:
Make the care of your patient your first concern

Protect and promote the health of patients and the public
  • Provide a good standard of practice and care
  • Keep your professional knowledge and skills up to date
  • Recognise and work within the limits of your competence
  • Work with colleagues in the ways that best serve patients' interests

Treat patients as individuals and respect their dignity
  • Treat patients politely and considerately
  • Respect patients' right to confidentiality

Work in partnership with patients
  • Listen to patients and respond to their concerns and preferences
  • Give patients the information they want or need in a way they can understand
  • Respect patients' right to reach decisions with you about their treatment and care
  • Support patients in caring for themselves to improve and maintain their health

Be honest and open and act with integrity
  • Act without delay if you have good reason to believe that you or a colleague may be putting patients at risk
  • Never discriminate unfairly against patients or colleagues
  • Never abuse your patients' trust in you or the public's trust in the profession.

Tell him that if he comes to your hospital as a patient, you and your team will investigate it
Tell him to go see a GP urgently
Tell him it is most likely cancer
questions:
During a family meeting, your cousin asks you if you could offer him some medical advice. He says he has been having intermittent swelling of some glands in his neck and feels like he has lost some weight. He asks you if you can give him a diagnosis.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
Option D is the most appropriate as you are directing your relative to a professional who is not related to them, making it likely he can get a prompt assessment to rule out sinister causes of his symptoms.

Option A is still appropriate as you are not offering any medical advice yourself. However, it is less appropriate than option D, as going through the GP would be the appropriate pathway in this situation. Using connections to get him seen quickly would also be inappropriate.

Option C is less appropriate, as it indicates you will be handling the matter yourself. However, it is better than the two remaining options as it implies that he will still be coming to the hospital as a formal patient, following a patient pathway.

Option E is inappropriate. Not only are you not supposed to give medical advice to your relatives, but in this case, you are going so far as to give him a hasty sinister diagnosis. It might prompt him to seek medical advice urgently, but it might also cause him unduly stress even though there are other differential diagnoses for his symptoms.

Option B is entirely inappropriate. Not only are you responsible for the medical care of your relative, but you are also doing so in secret.

title: GMC: treating friends, family and colleagues
body: The GMC guidance of 'Good practice in prescribing and managing medicines and device's says that wherever possible you must avoid prescribing for yourself or anyone with whom you have a close personal relationship, and they state that 'We expect our registrants to follow our guidance'.

Use the Mental Health Act to detain Alfred
Ask a senior colleague for advice
Assess Alfred's mental capacity
Sign the relevant paperwork to discharge Alfred
Advise Alfred that you believe he is making the wrong decision and he should reconsider
Administer a benzodiazepine to calm Alfred down
Provide Alfred the relevant paperwork for self-discharge
questions:
A 45-year-old male named Alfred is admitted following loss of consciousness in his local pub. On examination he has signs consistent with a stroke. On regaining consciousness he is confused and insists he wants to leave the ward despite you explaining to him that an urgent CT scan is required. What should you do next?

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes: It is important to provide Alfred with enough information so he can make an informed decision (A).  This discussion may also result in you addressing any concerns that he has.  As part of the discussion it is also essential to start considering Alfred's mental capacity (D) as this may impact on the decision making process.  This is clearly a complex task and it would be advisable to seek help from a senior colleague as soon as possible (C).

questions:
You are an FY2 placement on an orthopaedic firm and are one of seven other junior doctors on the team. The multi-disciplinary team (MDT) meeting each day is led by one of the physios, and no other members of the team ever say anything. Each day you or one of your junior colleagues are the most senior medic in attendance. You are concerned that important information relevant to the patients' discharge gets missed as a result of the physiotherapist's dominance.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This question assesses your understanding of the doctor's role when it comes leadership and management. See http://www.gmc-uk.org/guidance/ethicalguidance/managementfordoctors.asp for more information.

Improving the MDT meeting will be beneficial for patient care, and therefore if you identify it as an issue, it is appropriate that you take action. Hence option D and E as key action points in this. Option F is also good as it will enable both: your reflection from the events, and also make the consultant aware so that future rotations can continue the work. Options A and C do not improve the situation. Option B is probably unsustainable and does not involve the rest of your team. The on-call consultant would not be the person to go to in order to discuss these changes. Option H does not show you taking the initiative so is also not a particularly good option.
